and shall allege that the complaining party is the owner or legal occupant of
the property upon which the vehicle is parked or standing.
   C.   Upon filing of the complaint by the property owner or legal occupant,
and if there appears to be proper cause to believe the provisions of this title
have been violated, the police department shall cause the vehicle to be
impounded from the property and placed in storage. (2000 Code §
15-1209)
15-1210: VEHICLES PARKED OVERTIME:
Any unattended vehicle which has been parked for more than one hour in excess
of the time allowed for parking in any place shall be impounded, and any
vehicle parked in violation of section
15-704 of this title, regarding more than twenty four (24) hours, shall be
impounded. (2000 Code §
15-1210)
15-1211: VEHICLES BLOCKING FIRE EXITS OR HYDRANTS:
Any vehicle illegally parked in such a manner that it blocks a fire escape
ladder, device or exit or blocks ready access to a fire hydrant shall be
impounded. (2000 Code §
15-1211)
15-1212: VEHICLES PARKED IN INTERSECTION:
Any unattended vehicle illegally parked in any street intersection shall be
impounded. A disabled vehicle in an intersection with the person in charge of
the vehicle being present, shall be moved out of the intersection and to the
nearest available legal parking space at the street curbing. (2000 Code §
15-1212)
15-1213: STOLEN VEHICLES; RECOVERY BY POLICE:
   A.   Whenever a stolen vehicle is located by police and the registered owner
cannot be found within a reasonable time, not exceeding one hour, or cannot be
determined from the registration papers or other identifying media in the
vehicle or from records or information available from reports of stolen cars,
the vehicle may be removed to the nearest authorized place to impoundment and
the registered owner of the vehicle shall be notified of the location of the
place of impoundment as soon as possible by the police department.
   B.   If the registered owner is identified, located and notified of the
recovery of the stolen vehicle, the owner shall be given the right to make his
own arrangement for the removal of the vehicle within the period of one hour
from the time he is actually notified of its recovery, and if the owner is
unable or unwilling to effect the removal within the time specified, the
vehicle may be impounded. (2000 Code §
15-1213)
15-1214: VEHICLES WITH OUTSTANDING TRAFFIC CITATIONS:
Any vehicle for which two (2) or more citations have been issued pursuant to
this title for violation of an ordinance, and have not been presented as
required, may be impounded if parked in violation of any provision of this
title. (2000 Code §
15-1214)
CHAPTER 13
PENALTIES
SECTION:
15-1301: Obedience To Traffic Code
15-1302: Penalties
15-1301: OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC CODE:
   A.   It is an offense against the city for any person to do any act
forbidden or to fail to perform any act required by this title.
   B.   It is an offense against the city for the parent of any child or for
the guardian of any ward to authorize or knowingly permit any such child or
ward to violate any of the provisions of this title.
   C.   It is an offense for any person to authorize or knowingly to permit any
vehicle registered in his or her name to be driven or to stand or to be parked
in violation of any of the provisions of this title. (2000 Code §
15-1301)
15-1302: PENALTIES:
Every person violating any of the provisions of this title containing the
traffic laws of the city shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction
thereof, shall be fined or punished as provided in section
1-108 of this code. (2000 Code §
15-1302)
CHAPTER 14
COMPRESSION BRAKES
SECTION:
15-1401: Definitions
15-1402: Use Of Engine Compression Brake Prohibited
15-1403: Signage
15-1404: Penalty
15-1401: DEFINITIONS:
ENGINE COMPRESSION BRAKE: Shall mean any device that utilizes air compression
and/or rapid release of compressed air in the cylinders of diesel engines to
slow or retard vehicle speed. (Ord. 289, 6-13-2013)
15-1402: USE OF ENGINE COMPRESSION BRAKE PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for the operator of a motor vehicle to engage, or allow to
be engaged, operate, or use an engine compression brake, or any similar
mechanical exhaust device designed to aid in the deceleration of any vehicle
which results in the emission of excessive and loud noise from the vehicle,
while the vehicle is operated on any public roadway within the corporate limits
of the City of Stroud, Oklahoma. (Ord. 289, 6-13-2013)
15-1403: SIGNAGE:
The City is authorized to place traffic control signs and/or devices in the
appropriate locations as needed which say "Engine Compression Braking
Prohibited within City Limits". (Ord. 289, 6-13-2013)
15-1404: PENALTY:
Any person convicted of violating this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor
and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or
incarceration of a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both. Each
violation shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 289, 6-13-2013)
CHAPTER 15
UTILITY TERRAIN VEHICLES
SECTION:
15-1501: Definition
15-1502: Requirements
15-1501: DEFINITION:
A utility terrain vehicle (UTV) is defined as a vehicle designed for operation
off of the highway, suspended on four (4) tires, has a steering wheel for
steering control and has one seat to accommodate a driver and at least one
passenger seat sitting side by side. This vehicle shall also have headlamp
lights and brake lights. This definition does not include all terrain vehicles
(ATVs) or motorcycle dirt bikes. (Ord. 331, 8-10-2017)
15-1502: REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   The operator shall be a licensed driver, who shall be at least sixteen
(16) years of age.
   B.   UTVs may be operated twenty four (24) hours per day on the City streets
of Stroud, Oklahoma.
   C.   All other traffic laws applicable to automobiles or trucks shall be
applicable to UTVs. (Ord. 331, 8-10-2017)
TITLE 16
TRANSPORTATION
CHAPTER 1
RAILROADS
SECTION:
16-101: Railroads To Improve Streets And Alleys
16-102: Sidewalks To Be Constructed By Railroads
16-103: Railroad Trains Not To Block Streets
16-104: Climbing On Moving Trains
16-105: Speed Limit
16-106: Penalty
16-101: RAILROADS TO IMPROVE STREETS AND ALLEYS:
When a railway occupies any portion of a street with its tracks running in a
general direction of such street, either on or adjacent thereto, the railway
company shall improve the space between its tracks and two feet (2') on either
side thereof in the same manner that the remainder of the street is to be, or
has been, improved, or with such other satisfactory material as the council by
motion or resolution may approve. In case any railway company shall occupy an
alley with its track or tracks, the company shall improve, gutter, drain and
grade such alley, and shall surface or pave it with the same material which is
to be, or has been, used on the alley, or with such other satisfactory material
as the council by motion or resolution may approve. When more than one track
crosses a street within a distance of one hundred feet (100'), measuring from
inside rail to inside rail, the railroad company shall grade, gutter, drain and
curb the street area between its tracks, and surface or pave it with the same
material which the city is to use or has used, on the street. Railroad
companies shall keep all such improvements made by them in a good state of
repair at all times. (2000 Code §
16-101)
16-102: SIDEWALKS TO BE CONSTRUCTED BY RAILROADS:
Railway companies shall construct sidewalks crossing their rights of way, using
the same material as is used in adjacent sidewalks insofar as this is
practicable under the circumstances. They shall construct sidewalks on both
sides of the streets when both sides are used by pedestrians. The company shall
keep such sidewalks in a good state of repair at all times. (2000 Code §
16-102)
16-103: RAILROAD TRAINS NOT TO BLOCK STREETS:
It is unlawful for the directing officer or person in charge of any railroad
train or railroad car to direct the operation of or to operate the same in such
manner as to prevent the use of any street for purposes of travel for a period
of time longer than five (5) minutes, unless the railroad train or car is
involved in an accident or having engine trouble. (2000 Code §
16-103)
16-104: CLIMBING ON MOVING TRAINS:
It is unlawful for any person to climb upon, hold to or in any manner attach
himself to, any railway train, locomotive or railway car, while such is in
motion, within the city, unless such person is acting in line of duty. (2000
Code §
16-104)
16-105: SPEED LIMIT:
It is unlawful to drive, pull, move or operate a locomotive, train, or any
other rolling stock of a railroad at a speed of more than twenty five (25)
miles per hour within the corporate limits of the city. (2000 Code §
16-105)
16-106: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who shall perform any unlawful act as defined
by any provision of this chapter, or who shall otherwise violate any provision
of this chapter, shall be guilty of misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be
fined as provided in section
1-108 of this code. (2000 Code §
16-106)
CHAPTER 2
TAXIS AND OTHER VEHICLES FOR HIRE
SECTION:
16-201: Taxicab Defined
16-202: Registration
16-203: Application For Registration
16-204: Certificate
16-205: Inspection
16-206: Operation Of Taxi While Intoxicated Prohibited
16-207: Cab Stand
16-208: Public Liability Insurance
16-209: License Fee
16-210: Chauffeur's License And Violation Of Law
16-211: Penalty
16-201: TAXICAB DEFINED:
The term "taxicab", as used in this chapter, shall be construed to mean any and
all motor vehicles used by any person, firm or corporation within the city
limits for hire. (2000 Code §
16-201)
16-202: REGISTRATION:
All taxicabs and other vehicles offered to or used by the public for hire
within the city limits shall be registered with the city clerk. (2000 Code §
16-202)
16-203: APPLICATION FOR REGISTRATION:
Any person, firm or corporation using a taxicab or motor vehicle for hire, as
mentioned in this chapter, shall file his application in writing with the city
clerk showing:
   A.   The name of the owner;
   B.   The name of the operator of such vehicle;
   C.   The purpose for which such vehicle is offered to or used by the public;
   D.   The serial number or engine number of each such motor vehicle; and
   E.   A description of such vehicle by make and model. (2000 Code §
16-203)
16-204: CERTIFICATE:
When such application is filed, the city clerk shall register such taxi or
vehicle in a book to be kept by him for such purpose, and shall issue to the
owner thereof a certificate showing such registration and the purpose for which
such taxi or vehicle is offered to the public for hire. Such certificate shall
be at all times carried in the taxi or vehicle and displayed in a place visible
by passengers of such vehicle. Such certificate may be transferred from one
vehicle to another by the owner to whom the certificate was granted upon giving
notice to the city clerk of such transfer, and by registering the serial number
of the motor and description of the vehicle to which the certificate is
transferred. (2000 Code §
16-204)
16-205: INSPECTION:
Each taxicab shall be inspected at least once every six (6) months by a
competent mechanic and his certificate of inspection shall be displayed in
plain sight within the vehicle, showing that brakes, tires, steering apparatus,
horn and lights have been inspected and found to be in good condition. Such
certificate of inspection shall be signed by the mechanic making the inspection
and by the chief of police every six (6) months. The chief of police may
require an additional inspection by a competent mechanic of any such motor
vehicle at any time he deems it necessary. (2000 Code §
16-205)
16-206: OPERATION OF TAXI WHILE INTOXICATED PROHIBITED:
No person shall be permitted to operate a taxicab while under the influence of
intoxicating liquors, and for this purpose, the drinking of any alcoholic
beverage in any amount, shall be construed and considered enough to make such
driver under the influence of intoxicating drink. (2000 Code §
16-206)
16-207: CAB STAND:
No person, firm or corporation shall be permitted to use the parking areas of
the city in which to park the taxicab vehicles, or from which to solicit
business, except in such places as the council shall from time to time
designate. (2000 Code §
16-207)
16-208: PUBLIC LIABILITY INSURANCE:
   A.   All owners and operators of taxicabs and vehicles for hire, as herein
designated, shall purchase, and have in full force and effect at all times
during which such taxi or vehicle is operated within the city, a policy of
public liability insurance covering any person, firm or corporation who might
suffer injury or damage by reason of negligence of the owner or operator of the
motor vehicle or vehicles for hire, arising from the ownership or operation
thereof. The public liability insurance shall be for the following minimum
limits:
      1.   For bodily injury to any one person, one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000.00);
      2.   For bodily injury to two (2) or more persons arising out of any one
accident, two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00); and
      3.   For property damage, fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00).
   B.   In addition thereto, all taxis shall be required to carry minimum limit
liability insurance coverage required to fully comply with the financial
responsibility laws of the state. There shall be no maximum limits for the
amount of such insurance carried. A certificate showing the above insurance
coverage shall be deposited with the city clerk for each taxicab operated for
hire within the city. (2000 Code §
16-208)
16-209: LICENSE FEE:
At the time of registration of the taxicab and for the purpose of defraying the
expenses of police supervision, inspection and issuance of certificate herein
provided for, the owner of each taxicab shall pay a yearly license fee as set
by the council for the first vehicle and a fee as set by the council for each
additional vehicle. The payments shall be for the remainder of the fiscal year
of payment of license fees as provided in this chapter and there shall be
license fees for each year thereafter. (2000 Code §
16-209)
16-210: CHAUFFEUR'S LICENSE AND VIOLATION OF LAW:
Any person operating a taxicab shall be required to possess a chauffeur's
license issued by the state department of public safety. If the operator of any
such vehicle shall be convicted in any court within the state for the violation
of any law pertaining to the possession, use or sale of intoxicating liquors
while operating the motor vehicle, his permit to operate the taxicab within the
city or any other vehicles for hire shall immediately and automatically be
revoked. Such person shall not be permitted to operate a vehicle for hire
within the city for a period of one year from that date. Upon two (2) such
convictions, the person shall not be permitted to operate such motor vehicle
within the city again. (2000 Code §
16-210)
16-211: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who violates any of the provisions or sections
of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of an offense against the city and, upon
conviction or a plea of guilty thereof, shall be fined as provided in section
1-108 of this code. (2000 Code §
16-211)
CHAPTER 3
AIRPORT
SECTION:
16-301: Standards And Regulations
16-301: STANDARDS AND REGULATIONS:
   A.   There is hereby adopted the Minimum Standards for Stroud Municipal
Airport to be effective April 10, 2014. The provisions of such Minimum
Standards may be amended from time to time by resolution of the City of Stroud,
Oklahoma.
   B.   There is hereby adopted the Rules and Regulations for Stroud Municipal
Airport to be effective April 10, 2014. The provisions of such Rules and
Regulations may be amended from time to time by resolution of the City of
Stroud, Oklahoma.
   C.   The provisions of said Minimum Standards for Stroud Municipal Airport
and the Rules and Regulations for Stroud Municipal Airport are hereby referred
to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this chapter.
   D.   No less than three (3) copies of such Minimum Standards and such Rules
and Regulations shall be on file in the Office of the City Clerk and available
for public inspection during normal City Hall business hours. In addition, such
Minimum Standards and Rules and Regulations shall be publicly posted at Stroud
Municipal Airport with copies being available for public inspection and
distribution. (Ord. 295, 4-10-2014)
TITLE 17
UTILITIES
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
17-101: Application For Utility Service
17-102: Penalty For Connecting To System Without Permit
17-103: Service Pipes And Lines; How Installed
17-104: Separate Service
17-105: Bills; When Payable, Delinquency
17-105-1: Utility Billing; Notices; Discontinuation Of Services
17-105-2: Allocation And Application Of Utility Payments
17-106: Rights Reserved To Interrupt Service
17-107: City Not Liable
17-108: Damaging Equipment
17-109: To Be Used Only On Premises
17-110: Interference With Mains, Fire Hydrants
17-111: Tampering With Meters Unlawful
17-112: Evidence Of Violation Of Tampering
17-113: Discontinuance Of Service For Tampering
17-114: Unlawful To Climb Upon Or About Water Tower
17-115: Procedure For Governing Board To Fix Future Utility Rates
17-116: Right Of Access To Utility Meters
17-117: Trimming Of Trees And Shrubs
17-118: Ambulance Service Subsidization Fee
17-101: APPLICATION FOR UTILITY SERVICE:
Every person, firm or corporation desiring to have his premises connected with
any of the city utilities, water, electric, sewer or trash collection, shall
make application to the city clerk, shall sign a contract therefor upon a
printed form to be furnished for that purpose, and shall pay to the clerk the
regular fees and deposits for installation of the service. The clerk shall
issue a permit authorizing any regular plumber or electrician to make the
proper connections for water, sewer or electric service. (2000 Code §
17-101)
17-102: PENALTY FOR CONNECTING TO SYSTEM WITHOUT PERMIT:
Any person, whether as owner, plumber, electrician, servant, agent or employee,
who shall make any connection to the water, sewer or electric system without
first having secured a permit as provided herein, shall be deemed guilty of an
offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined as provided in section
1-108 of this code. (2000 Code §
17-102)
17-103: SERVICE PIPES AND LINES; HOW INSTALLED:
All service pipes or lines shall be located in such manner that the supply for
each separate house or premises shall be controlled by a separate stopcock or
switch so placed as to be readily accessible from the outside of the house.
(2000 Code §
17-103)
17-104: SEPARATE SERVICE:
Every separate premises supplied must have its own separate service connection
with the mains or lines, and the premises so supplied shall not be allowed to
supply water, sewer or electricity to any other premises. (2000 Code §
17-104)
17-105: BILLS; WHEN PAYABLE, DELINQUENCY:
   A.   All bills for water, electricity, sewer, garbage, and all other monthly
charges made by the city, shall be payable to the city clerk or such other
person as is designated by the city manager at the office of the city clerk on
the first day of each month. If a bill is not paid on or by the tenth day of
the month following that in which the water, electricity or other services were
used, the bill will be declared to be delinquent. A penalty of seven percent
(7%) of the amount due on any delinquent bill will be charged, and the city
clerk or other designated person is hereby directed to collect such penalty at
the time the bill is paid. The utility bill shall not be considered paid in
full until any penalties are also paid.
   B.   If any bill is not paid by four o'clock (4:00) P.M. on the fifteenth
day of the month, service may be discontinued beginning on the sixteenth day of
the month following the month in which the utility service was used. The
superintendent of the department, or such other person as the city manager may
designate, shall discontinue the city service to the premises after written
notice. The utility service shall not be turned on again until all arrearages
are paid in full, together with the penalty as above specified for shutting off
and turning on the city service. (Ord. 220, 4-12-2007)
   C.   If the superintendent of the department, or other designated person,
goes to the premises to shut off the service and the occupant pays the
superintendent or person prior to his shutting off the service, there shall be
added to the bill the sum as set by the council for the trip made by the
superintendent or person to shut off such services. All bills, penalties and
fees collected as hereinabove specified shall be paid over to the city clerk.
Nothing herein shall be construed as preventing the city from instituting suit
for the recovery of any delinquent accounts.
   D.   The city clerk may not accept payment of a water bill without payment
of the sewer service charge, nor shall the clerk accept payment of a sewer bill
without payment of the water bill. The failure to pay any utility bill in
accordance with subsections A and B of this section shall be grounds for
discontinuing any or all of the utility services furnished to the customer
whose bill is delinquent. (2000 Code §
17-105)
17-105-1: UTILITY BILLING; NOTICES; DISCONTINUATION OF SERVICES:
   A.   The city and the Stroud utilities authority are hereby authorized and
directed, with regard to invoices issued concerning utility customers, to take
the following actions:
      1.   In the event the invoiced utility services are not paid by the tenth
day of the month in which the invoice is generated, a "disconnect notice" shall
be mailed to the utility customer;
      2.   In the event the invoiced utility services, including late fees, are
not paid within five (5) days of the mailing of the "disconnect notice", the
utility services shall be disconnected without further notice to the utility
customer;
      3.   In the event the tenth day of the month falls on a Saturday, Sunday
or legal holiday, the due date shall be extended to the next business day
thereafter;
      4.   The "disconnect notice" shall be in a form prescribed by the city
and the Stroud utilities authority.
   B.   All late fees and reconnection fees as they currently exist shall
remain in full force and effect.
   C.   Failure of the utility customer to pay the entire amounts due or
incurred shall require the city and the Stroud utilities authority to terminate
services currently in effect as set forth hereinabove.
   D.   This section is made applicable as it pertains to each utility bill and
shall not be based on the number of utility accounts held in any single
customer's name. (Ord. 233, 8-14-2008)
17-105-2: ALLOCATION AND APPLICATION OF UTILITY PAYMENTS:
   A.   Definitions:
UTILITIES: The procurement or sale of electricity, water, sewage or garbage
disposal services sold by the city of Stroud or the Stroud utilities authority,
whether one or more.
UTILITY ACCOUNT: An account opened by an end user or purchaser of electricity,
water, sewage or garbage disposal services sold by the city of Stroud or the
Stroud utilities authority, whether the same shall be one or more services
purchased.
UTILITY CUSTOMER: The end user or purchaser of electricity, water, sewage or
garbage disposal services, regardless of the number of services purchased,
whether one or more.
UTILITY SERVICES: Those products or services sold to the public at large, such
as electricity, water, sewage or garbage disposal services. (Ord. 231, 6-12-
2008)
   B.   Payments Applied To: The city and the Stroud utilities authority are
hereby authorized and directed with regard to all payments made by utility
customers on their outstanding utility bills, to apply any amounts received
from the said utility customers: first to charges incurred for ambulance
subsidization fees and fees associated with certain natural disasters; and,
secondly, the remaining amounts received shall be applied on outstanding
charges for electricity, water, sewage and garbage removal fees incurred.
   C.   Terminate Services: Failure of the utility customer to pay the entire
amounts due or incurred shall require the city and the Stroud utilities
authority to terminate services currently in effect in accordance with the
existing policies and procedures.
   D.   Applicability: This section is made applicable as it pertains to each
utility bill and shall not be based on the number of utility accounts held in
any single customer's name. (Ord. 230, 5-8-2008)
17-106: RIGHTS RESERVED TO INTERRUPT SERVICE:
The city reserves the right to shut off the supply of water or electricity
without notice, for repairs, extensions, nonpayment of rates, or for any other
reason, and no liability shall attach therefrom. (2000 Code §
17-106)
17-107: CITY NOT LIABLE:
The city shall not be liable for any damage caused by the breaking of any pipes
or fixtures, stoppage or interruption of water or electricity, or for any
defect in the system. (2000 Code §
17-107)
17-108: DAMAGING EQUIPMENT:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to destroy or injure any water
pipe, hydrant, faucet, electric light wire, pole, transformer, or other
electrical, sewer or water equipment erected or placed by or belonging to the
city. (2000 Code §
17-108)
17-109: TO BE USED ONLY ON PREMISES:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to take any water or electricity
from any main, pipe or wire, except for use on the premises where the same is
located. (2000 Code §
17-109)
17-110: INTERFERENCE WITH MAINS, FIRE HYDRANTS:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to disturb, interfere with, open,
operate, close, turn on, turn off, attach any pipe or hose to, or connect
anything with any fire hydrant, or any stopvalve or stopcock belonging to the
city. However, this section shall not apply to any member of the fire
department when in the lawful discharge of his duties as such, or to any person
endeavoring to prevent or put out any fire in any lawful manner. (2000 Code §
17-110)
17-111: TAMPERING WITH METERS UNLAWFUL:
The tampering with water or electrical meters or meter boxes of the city, or
the placing of any bypass connection on or around the meters, or the use of any
other device tending to interfere with the proper registration of same is
unlawful. (2000 Code §
17-111)
17-112: EVIDENCE OF VIOLATION OF TAMPERING:
Evidence of the violation of section
17-111 of this chapter from information by a meter reader or other qualified
employees of the city, duly supported by affidavit or photograph, shall be
deemed prima facie evidence of the intent on the part of the person or persons
responsible for a residential/commercial utility account to violate the
provisions of section
17-111 of this chapter. (2000 Code §
17-112)
17-113: DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE FOR TAMPERING:
The superintendent of the department in charge, or his authorized
representative, is hereby directed to discontinue service to any person, firm
or corporation, found guilty of violation of section
17-111 of this chapter. Service shall not be resumed until the estimated cost
of the service that was used and diverted shall have been paid in full. (2000
Code §
17-113)
17-114: UNLAWFUL TO CLIMB UPON OR ABOUT WATER TOWER:
It is unlawful for any person to climb upon or about any city water tower or
standpipe, except in line of duty. (2000 Code §
17-114)
17-115: PROCEDURE FOR GOVERNING BOARD TO FIX FUTURE UTILITY RATES:
The mayor and city council, acting either as the governing board of the city or
as trustees of the Stroud utilities authority, may establish future rates for
utility services by ordinance, motion or resolution, as the case may be. (2000
Code §
17-115)
17-116: RIGHT OF ACCESS TO UTILITY METERS:
The city and the Stroud utilities authority, and any of their employees or
representatives, shall have the right to enter on any premises and grounds in
order to access any utility meters or equipment. Any person who wilfully
obstructs such access to meters or equipment shall be guilty of an offense.
(2000 Code §
17-116)
17-117: TRIMMING OF TREES AND SHRUBS:
   A.   In an effort to maintain utility easements and rights of way, the city
will try to maintain a minimum of twenty feet (20') of clearance from any
electrical wire or guywire from all trees, shrubs, bushes, fencing and other
structures in the city utility easements and rights of way that are part of the
municipal electric system. The city has the right to trim or remove any tree
that is in, or growing into, the city utility easement or right of way.
   B.   The trimming or removal of any tree in the city utility easement or
right of way shall be the decision of the electric supervisor. Notification
will be given to the property resident and/or owner and request made that
written permission be given for said tree trimming or removal. Refusal to sign
said resident and/or owner permission form will be referred to the city
manager; however, the ultimate decision making authority, regardless of
consent, lies with the city manager. In the event of an emergency, no
notification will be given to trim a tree or shrub that has in some way caused
or is causing an electrical outage.
   C.   Trees or shrubs that are grown in the city utility easements or rights
of way will be removed in the event of a repair or improvements to city water
and sewer lines. Notification will be given to the property owner for the need
to remove said plantings. Fences that are built onto the city utility easement
or right of way can and will be taken down in the event of a repair or
improvement to the city water or sewer lines. The repair or replacement of said
fence will be the responsibility of the property owner. (Ord. 208, 3-24-2006)
17-118: AMBULANCE SERVICE SUBSIDIZATION FEE:
   A.   The city and the Stroud utilities authority are hereby authorized and
directed to charge a fee in such amount as established by resolution of the
city council, per utility bill per month issued by the Stroud utilities
authority for the subsidization of any ambulance service contracted for by the
city and/or the Stroud utilities authority. This expense shall only be
applicable to each address which has utility service, and should multiple
utility services be connected at the same address, then in that event, the
utility customer shall receive one bill per address for ambulance services.
   B.   The provisions set forth in subsection A of this section shall be
effective with the incurrence of utility services effective May 1, 2008, and
shall be effective until repealed.
   C.   This section is made applicable as it pertains to each utility bill and
shall not be based on the number of utility accounts held in any single
customer's name. (Ord. 228, 4-29-2008; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 2
WATER SERVICE
SECTION:
17-201: Application To Make Connection To Water Mains; Tap Charge
17-202: Connections To Be Made In Accordance With Ordinance And Law
17-203: Water Deposit Required
17-204: Controlling The Quantity Of Fluoride In The Public Water Supply
17-205: Water Rates
17-206: Water Shortages; Declaration Of Emergency
17-207: Restriction On Water Use In Emergency
17-208: Proclamation And Notice Of Emergency
17-209: Grievances With Water Restrictions
17-210: Penalties
17-201: APPLICATION TO MAKE CONNECTION TO WATER MAINS; TAP CHARGE:
Any person desiring to make a connection to a water main of the city is
required to file a written application with the city clerk to make the
connection. A charge shall be levied for each new tap on the water mains of the
city, the amount to be set by resolution or motion of the council. Upon receipt
of the connection or tap charge, the city clerk is directed to issue such
permit. (2000 Code §
17-201)
17-202: CONNECTIONS TO BE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH ORDINANCE AND LAW:
Any person, firm or corporation who connects to the water mains of the city in
violation of this chapter or other ordinances of the city or the laws of the
state will be denied further water service until such ordinances and laws are
complied with. (2000 Code §
17-202)
17-203: WATER DEPOSIT REQUIRED:
Any person who desires to use water supplied by the city or Stroud utilities
authority shall put up with the city clerk as a meter deposit the amount which
is required by resolution or motion of the council. The council may establish
classifications of customers, such as residences, mobile homes and various
types of businesses for different deposit requirements. (2000 Code §
17-203)
17-204: CONTROLLING THE QUANTITY OF FLUORIDE IN THE PUBLIC WATER SUPPLY:
In order to protect the health and welfare of the citizens of the city, from
and after May 11, 1981, the quantity of fluoride in the public water supply
shall be controlled in such manner that the amount present in the water served
to the public shall be in conformity with the policy, and subsequent changes
thereto, established by the Oklahoma state board of health. (2000 Code §
17-204)
17-205: WATER RATES:
   A.   Residential And Commercial Customers: The water rate schedule for
residential and commercial customers shall be as set by the council by motion
or resolution. (2000 Code §
17-205; amd. Ord. 263, 8-11-2011)
   B.   Commercial Agriculture Users:
      1.   The term "commercial agriculture user" shall mean any person or
entity engaged in any type of agriculture pursuit for profit, although hobby
farms would also be included within this definition.
      2.   To further qualify as a "commercial agriculture user" for water rate
purposes as defined at subsection B1 of this section the user would be required
to meet the following criteria:
         a.   The physical location of the site shall be within the city limits
of Stroud, Oklahoma; and
         b.   The physical location of the site used for agriculture pursuits
must be of a size of no less than four (4) acres; and
         c.   The minimum annual (calculated on a continuous uninterrupted 12
month period of time) usage shall be not less than four million (4,000,000)
gallons annually.
      3.   It shall be the duty of the commercial agriculture user to provide
proof of the size of the area where the water is used in order to be qualified
for the commercial agriculture user rate.
      4.   The rate to be charged to the commercial agriculture user shall be
one dollar ninety cents ($1.90) per one thousand (1,000) gallons used and a
meter fee of thirty five dollars ($35.00) per month, charged each and every
month.
      5.   In the event the commercial agriculture user did not use four
million (4,000,000) gallons of water per annum for two (2) consecutive twelve
(12) month time periods, the utility customer rate would automatically revert
to the commercial rate then in effect.
      6.   In the event the agriculture use of water increased to four million
(4,000,000) gallons per annum the utility user would then again be eligible for
the commercial agriculture rate.
      7.   All other current rates for setting meters and the commercial rate
user base rate shall also apply.
      8.   The commercial agriculture rate shall apply only to treated water.
(Ord. 264, 11-10-2011, eff. 11-10-2011)
17-206: WATER SHORTAGES; DECLARATION OF EMERGENCY:
   A.   Whenever an emergency exists by reason of a shortage of water due to
inadequate supply, limited treatment or distribution capacity or failure of
equipment or material, the city manager, or his designee, is hereby authorized
to restrict or prohibit the use of water from the city water system.
   B.   An emergency exists whenever the city manager, or his designee,
reasonably determines that the city water system is unable or will within sixty
(60) days become unable to supply the full commercial and domestic needs of the
users thereof, including adequate fire protection. (2000 Code §
17-206)
17-207: RESTRICTION ON WATER USE IN EMERGENCY:
   A.   Upon the determination that such an emergency exists, the city manager,
or his designee, shall issue a proclamation declaring the emergency and setting
out with particularity an order restricting use of water from the city system.
The order may:
      1.   Restrict water usage during certain periods of the day or week or
according to any orderly and nondiscriminatory scheme; and
      2.   Prohibit usages not essential to public health and safety. The order
may be revised from time to time as the city manager, or his designee, deems
necessary.
   B.   A duly proclaimed emergency shall continue and the terms of the
proclamation shall be in force for thirty (30) days or until such time as the
city manager or his designee shall cause to be published a proclamation that
the emergency has ended, whichever is shorter, unless the board, by resolution
approved by a majority of all its members, votes to terminate the emergency and
proclamation upon a different date. (2000 Code §
17-207)
17-208: PROCLAMATION AND NOTICE OF EMERGENCY:
   A.   The proclamation required by section
17-207 of this chapter shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation
in the city and the community channel on cable television or, if there is no
such newspaper in which the proclamation may be published within twenty four
(24) hours after the emergency arises, publication shall be by posting a copy
of the proclamation in ten (10) prominent places in the city. The emergency
shall be in full force and effect upon publication. Substantial compliance with
this section is sufficient to effect the emergency.
   B.   Whenever a sudden or unexpected event so reduces the availability of
water or water pressure as to create an immediate threat to public health or
safety, the notice of the proclamation may be given by any reasonable means,
including electronic means. The emergency shall be in full force and effect
upon such notice. However, if any means other than that required in subsection
A of this section is used, the proclamation shall be republished in accordance
with subsection A of this section within twenty four (24) hours of the first
notice. (2000 Code §
17-208)
17-209: GRIEVANCES WITH WATER RESTRICTIONS:
Any person feeling aggrieved by a proclamation of the city manager, or his
designee, shall have the right to present the matter to the next regular or
special meeting of the city council or to any emergency session called to
discuss the water emergency. The board may exempt such aggrieved person, wholly
or in part, from compliance with the proclamation order upon a showing that
compliance creates an immediate threat to the person's health or safety. The
ruling of the council by a majority vote of all its members shall be final and
binding as to the continuance of any terms of the proclamation. Until and
unless the action of the city manager, or his designee, is modified or revoked
by action of the council, all water users shall be bound by the proclamation.
(2000 Code §
17-209)
17-210: PENALTIES:
Any person who in any manner directly or indirectly violates or permits others
under his supervision, custody or control to violate any term of a duly
published proclamation shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Any violation of the
provisions of the proclamation of the city manager, or his designee, or action
of the board, shall be punishable by a fine or imprisonment as provided in
section
1-108 of this code. (2000 Code §
17-210)
CHAPTER 3
ELECTRIC SERVICE
SECTION:
17-301: Electric Deposit Required
17-302: Provision Of Service; Rules For Initiating Service
17-303: Additional Supply To Points Beyond Meter
17-304: Electric Rates
17-305: Adjustments
17-306: Use Of Backup Generators
17-301: ELECTRIC DEPOSIT REQUIRED:
Any person who desires to use electricity supplied by the City shall put up
with the City Clerk as a meter deposit the amount which is required by
resolution or motion of the Council. The Council may establish classifications
of customers, such as residences, mobile homes and various types of businesses
for different deposit requirements. (2000 Code §
17-301)
17-302: PROVISION OF SERVICE; RULES FOR INITIATING SERVICE:
When the City is requested to provide electric power at an installation in the
City and the City is serving the area where such installation is to be made,
the following rules shall apply with regard to such request and installation:
   A.   For AC 60 HZ, single-phase, 120/240 volt service, no charge will be
made;
   B.   For the following electrical installations:
      1.   3-phase electrical service;
      2.   208 wye/120 voltage;
      3.   277/480 voltage;
      4.   120 y voltage; or
      5.   Any other unusual type of electrical requirements or voltage which
require special lines or equipment,
the City Manager, or person designated by the City Manager, shall prepare an
estimate of the cost of equipment and labor to make such installation, and the
entity requesting such service shall be required to do one of the following, or
a combination of the same:
         a.   Pay to the City an installation charge, not to exceed the
estimated cost for such installation; and
         b.   Enter into a contract with such customer for such period of time
so as to permit the City to be compensated for the costs of such installation
and to make charges to compensate the City for the cost of such installation if
the customer is disconnected before the end of such contract period. (2000 Code
§
17-302)
17-303: ADDITIONAL SUPPLY TO POINTS BEYOND METER:
When an electrical customer requests a separate supply or other voltages of
electrical current at other points beyond the initial delivery and metering
point, the customer will be charged the cost of installing the additional
equipment, and separate meters shall be installed at such additional points of
delivery and the electrical current separately metered and billed at each point
of delivery. (2000 Code §
17-303)
17-304: ELECTRIC RATES:
All electric current billed by the City shall be on the meter rates as set by
the Council by motion or resolution. (2000 Code §
17-304)
17-305: ADJUSTMENTS:
   A.   If the results of any meter test, whether requested by the customer or
performed at the option of the City, show that a meter registers inaccurately
by more than two percent (2%) fast or slow, the City will correct the
customer's utility bills, using the percent of error as the factor for
calculating adjustments:
      1.   Fast Meters: The City shall credit to the customer's account the
amount overcharged during previous billing periods, not to exceed six (6)
months.
      2.   Slow Meters: The City may charge for the electricity or water
consumed, but not included in bills previously rendered, for a period not to
exceed six (6) months.
      3.   Clerical, Technical Errors: If a meter or account record is found to
have an incorrect register, connection, multiplier, or constant, or if a meter
is found not to register or to have been registering intermittently for any
period, or if a clerical error of any nature has been made on the account, the
error shall be corrected and the account adjusted. Billable usage may be
estimated based on such information as is available from the City records and
as is deemed reasonable in comparison to previous usage at the same account or
similar usages at comparable accounts.
   B.   When the error is adverse to the customer, a credit adjustment will be
made to the account for the amount charged due to incorrect metering or due to
errors in billing calculations for the period of time that the bills were in
error, but not to exceed six (6) months. When the error is adverse to the City,
the City may charge the customer not to exceed six (6) months. (Ord. 200, 2-10-
2005)
17-306: USE OF BACKUP GENERATORS:
   A.   The City of Stroud, Oklahoma, does hereby enact this section regulating
the use of portable and stationary electric generators, prohibiting the use of
portable and stationary electric generators after disconnection of electrical
utilities for non-payment of utility services and establishing penalties for
violation of this section.
   B.   The connection of portable and stationary electrical generation
devices, if not properly installed, may lead to the death or injury of persons
servicing the units and can further lead to serious damage of the electrical
delivery device if not properly installed. As such, it is necessary to
establish rules, regulations and penalties for unauthorized or improper
installation of these devices.
   C.   Generators for temporary back-up service shall not be considered a
primary power source if City electrical services are operating and available
and shall be permitted as long as the generator cannot be interconnected or
linked in any manner to the City's permanent service. A permit and inspection
is required to use any generator for back-up electrical service for any
structure using the City electrical system.
   D.   Portable generating sources may only be connected through an approved
disconnect switch. This switch must positively disconnect the utility feed
before connecting the generator to the customer load.
   E.   Portable or stationary generators shall not be used for the replacement
of electrical service when a service has been disconnected for non-payment of
utility services.
   F.   1. Any person who violates this section shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, is punishable as provided in section
1-108 of this Code.
      2.   In addition to proceedings under subsection F1 of this section, the
City is entitled to pursue authority to pursue all other criminal and civil
remedies to which it is entitled under authority of Oklahoma Statutes or other
ordinances against a person continuing the prohibited acts.
      3.   Each day that this section is violated shall constitute a separate
offense and shall be treated as such. (Ord. 290, 11-14-2013)
CHAPTER 4
SEWER SERVICE
SECTION:
17-401: Conformance To Rules And Regulations
17-402: Inspection
17-403: Persons To Comply With Rules And Regulations
17-404: Charge To Be Made For Permit
17-405: Compliance With Ordinances And Laws
17-406: Sewer Service User Charges
17-407: Nonresident Users
17-408: Water Deposits For Sewer
17-409: Prohibited Discharges
17-410: Permits Required
17-411: New Sewers And Connections
17-412: Discharges
17-413: Interceptors Required
17-414: Penalty
17-401: CONFORMANCE TO RULES AND REGULATIONS:
All connections to the sewers of the City shall conform to the rules and
regulations prescribed by the City and the (IPC) International Plumbing Code
2009. (Ord. 280, 2-14-2013)
17-402: INSPECTION:
It is the duty of the plumbing inspector, or other person to be designated by
the City Manager, to inspect the sewer connection after it is completed by the
applicant. If the person doing the inspecting under authority of the City
disapproves the connection and finds that it does not conform to the rules and
regulations of the City, he shall notify the applicant of his disapproval, and
the applicant shall immediately comply with the objections of the inspector.
(Ord. 280, 2-14-2013)
17-403: PERSONS TO COMPLY WITH RULES AND REGULATIONS:
No person, firm or corporation shall hereafter make any connection on any
public sewer or any connection on any private sewer which in turn is connected
with a public sewer, without complying with the rules and regulations herein
set out. No person, firm or corporation shall connect more than one building to
a single lateral leading to the public sewer system of the City. (Ord. 280, 2-
14-2013)
17-404: CHARGE TO BE MADE FOR PERMIT:
A charge prescribed by section
17-403 of this chapter for each connection made on the sanitary sewer system of
the City, regardless of whether the connection is made on what has heretofore
been designated as a public sewer or a private sewer, is hereby levied for the
right of the person, firm or corporation to make the connection to the sanitary
sewer system of the City. It is hereby declared to be the duty of the City
Clerk to make this collection for issuing a permit to the applicant. Fees for
each application shall be set from time to time by the Stroud City Council.
(Ord. 280, 2-14-2013)
17-405: COMPLIANCE WITH ORDINANCES AND LAWS:
Any person who connects to the sewers of the City in violation of this chapter
or any other ordinance of the City or of the laws of the State will be denied
further sewer service until such ordinances and laws are complied with. It
shall be the duty of the plumbing inspector, or other person designated by the
City Manager, to disconnect any sewer and water which have not been connected
in compliance with the ordinances and laws. (Ord. 280, 2-14-2013)
17-406: SEWER SERVICE USER CHARGES:
   A.   Charges: For the purpose of providing funds for the maintenance of the
sanitary sewerage system of the City and for other purposes, there is hereby
fixed and established charges for the use of the sanitary sewerage system to be
levied against each respective user thereof with the City in such amounts and
according to such classifications of users as the Council by resolution or
motion may determine. A copy of the current charges in effect shall be kept on
file in the City Clerk's Office.
   B.   Calculation Of Sewer Charges: Rates for sewer charges shall be set from
time to time by the City Council as set in subsection A of this section.
There shall be separate procedures for commercial and residential use charges.
      1.   Commercial accounts, use charges, shall be based on their usage of
water on a month to month basis.
      2.   Residential accounts, shall be charged as follows: The monthly user
charge will be based upon the average monthly water usage during the months of
November, December, January, February and March and each residential
contributor shall pay a monthly user fee based upon the average number of
gallons of water used each month for said five (5) month period. (Ord. 309, 9-
10-2015)
17-407: NONRESIDENT USERS:
All users of the City sanitary sewerage system having connections outside the
corporate limits of the City shall be charged one and one-half (11/2) times the
scheduled rates currently in effect, as set by the Council. The City does not
obligate itself to furnish sanitary sewer service to any persons whomsoever,
but will furnish such service as is reasonable within its discretion and
financial ability to do. (Ord. 280, 2-14-2013)
17-408: WATER DEPOSITS FOR SEWER:
All deposits made by users of City water, as required by the City ordinances to
guarantee payment of water bills, may be also applied to pay delinquent sewer
service charges of the user who made the deposit. (Ord. 280, 2-14-2013)
17-409: PROHIBITED DISCHARGES:
   A.   No person may discharge to public sewers any waste which by itself or
by interaction with other wastes may:
      1.   Injure or interfere with wastewater treatment processes or
facilities;
      2.   Constitute a hazard to humans or animals; or
      3.   Create a hazard in receiving waters of the wastewater treatment
plant effluent.
   B.   All discharges shall be prohibited except those that meet the criteria
for "domestic wastewater". (BOD) biochemical oxygen demand concentration shall
not exceed two hundred ten milligrams per liter (210 mg/L) (maximum limit for
average domestic wastewater). (SS) suspended solids shall not exceed two
hundred milligrams per liter (200 mg/L) (maximum limit for average domestic
wastewater).
   C.   All industrial discharges are prohibited. At the present time, there
are no industrial users in the City. If an industrial user should desire to
locate in the City and make use of the sewerage system, an industrial user
system will be initiated in accordance with EPA and State regulations at that
time to compensate for the use of the system.
   D.   Any new connections from inflow sources into the sanitary sewer
portions of the sewer system shall be prohibited. (Ord. 280, 2-14-2013)
17-410: PERMITS REQUIRED:
   A.   Contributing Industries And Pretreatment Requirements:
      1.   The following pollutants shall not be introduced into a publicly
owned treatment works (POTW) facility, defined in 40 CFR 403.3(o) as any
devices and systems used in storage, treatment, recycling, and reclamation of
municipal sewage and industrial wastes of a liquid nature. It also includes
sewers, pipes, and other conveyances only if they convey wastewater to a POTW
treatment plant. The term also means the municipality as defined in section 502
(4) of the Act, which has jurisdiction over the indirect discharges to and from
such treatment works.
         a.   Pollutants which create a fire or explosion hazard in the POTW
facility, including, but not limited to, waste streams with a closed cup
flashpoint of less than sixty degrees Celsius (60°C) (140°F) using the test
methods specified in 40 CFR 261.21;
         b.   Pollutants which will cause corrosive structural damage to the
POTW, but in no case discharges with pH lower than 5.0, unless the works are
specifically designed to accommodate such discharges;
         c.   Solid or viscous pollutants in amounts which will cause
obstruction to the flow in the POTW, resulting in interference;
         d.   Any pollutant, including oxygen demanding pollutants (e.g., BOD),
released in a discharge at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration which
will cause interference with the POTW;
         e.   Heat in amounts which will inhibit biological activity in the
POTW resulting in interference but in no case heat in such quantities that the
temperature at the POTW treatment plant exceeds forty degrees Celsius (40°C)
(104°F) unless the approval authority, upon request of the POTW, approves
alternate temperature limits;
         f.   Petroleum oil, non-biodegradable cutting oil, or products of
mineral oil origin in amounts that will cause interference or pass through;
         g.   Pollutants which result in the presence of toxic gases, vapors,
or fumes within the POTW in a quantity that may cause acute worker health and
safety problems; and
         h.   Any trucked or hauled pollutants, except at discharge points
designated by the POTW.
      2.   The permittee shall require any indirect discharger to the treatment
works to comply with the reporting requirements of sections 204(b), 307, and
308 of the Act, including any requirements established under 40 CFR part 403.
      3.   The permittee shall provide adequate notice of the following:
         a.   Any new introduction of pollutants into the treatment works from
an indirect discharger which would be subject to sections 301 and 306 of the
Act and/or sections 40 CFR 405 - 499 if it were directly discharging those
pollutants;
         b.   Any substantial change in the volume or character of pollutants
being introduced into the treatment works by a source introducing pollutants
into the treatment works at the time of issuance of the permit; and
         c.   Any notice shall include information on: 1) the quality and
quantity of effluent to be introduced into the treatment works and 2) any
anticipated impact of the change on the quality or quantity of effluent to be
discharged from the POTW. (Ord. 280, 2-14-2013)
17-411: NEW SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS:
   A.   The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall
conform to the requirements of the City Building Code and other applicable
rules and regulations of the City.
   B.   All new sanitary sewage works shall be designed and constructed in
accordance with the requirements of the Oklahoma State Department of Health
regulations.
   C.   When a public sewer becomes available within two hundred feet (200'),
the building sewer shall be connected to the sewer within sixty (60) days.
(Ord. 280, 2-14-2013)
17-412: DISCHARGES:
No person(s) shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following
described waters or wastes to any public sewers:
   A.   Any liquids, solids, or gases which by reason of their nature or
quantity are, or may be, sufficient either alone or by interaction with other
substances to cause fire or explosion or be injurious in any other way to the
wastewater disposal system or to the operation of the system. Prohibited
materials include, but are not limited to, gasoline, kerosene, naphtha,
benzene, toluene, xylene, ethers, alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, peroxides,
chlorates, perchlorates, bromates, carbides, hydrides, and sulfide.
   B.   Solid or viscous substances which will cause obstruction to the flow in
a sewer or other interference with the operation of the wastewater treatment
facilities such as, but not limited to, grease, garbage with particles greater
than one-half inch (1/2") in any dimension, animal guts or tissues, paunch
manure, bones, hair, hides or fleshings, entrails, whole blood, feathers,
ashes, cinders, sand, spent lime, stone or marble dust, metal, glass, straw,
shavings, grass clippings, rags, spent grains, spent hops, waste paper, wood,
plastic, asphalt residues, residues from refining or processing of fuel or
lubricating oil, mud or glass grinding or polishing wastes.
   C.   Any wastewater containing toxic pollutants in sufficient quantity,
either singly or by interaction with other pollutants, to inhibit or disrupt
any wastewater treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, or
create a toxic effect in the receiving waters of the wastewater disposal
system. A toxic pollutant shall include any pollutant identified by the
Department of Environmental Quality (DEQ).
   D.   Any waste water having a pH less than 5.0 or greater than 9.0 or waste
water having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard
to structures, equipment, and/or personnel of the waste water treatment system.
   E.   Any waste water having a temperature which will inhibit biological
activity in the (WWTP) waste water treatment plant resulting in interference,
but in no case waste water with a temperature at the introduction into the WWTP
which exceeds forty degrees Celsius (40°C) or one hundred four degrees
Fahrenheit (104°F).
   F.   Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to
such sewers as are specifically designed as storm sewers or to a natural outlet
approved by the City and other regulatory agencies. Industrial cooling water or
unpolluted process waters may be discharged to a storm sewer or natural outlet
on approval of the City and upon approval and the issuance of a discharge
permit by the City. (Ord. 280, 2-14-2013)
17-413: INTERCEPTORS REQUIRED:
   A.   For the purposes of this section the word "interceptor" shall mean a
device designed and installed so as to separate and retain deleterious,
hazardous or undesirable matter from normal waste and permit normal sewage or
liquid waste to discharge into the sewer system by gravity.
   B.   In any building, establishment, house, garage, place where vehicles are
washed or repaired, restaurants, service stations, car wash, grocery store,
school, other facilities that prepare any type of food products, nursing home,
assisted living centers, hospitals and any other place where sand, dirt,
gravel, oil, gasoline, grease or other grainy, deleterious or insoluble matter
is washed or discharged into the sanitary sewer system of the City, the drain
into which such materials are discharged shall be equipped with a sand trap or
interceptor which shall be so designed and constructed as to be readily
accessible for cleaning and inspection and that part of the discharge line
which is within the trap or interceptor leading from such interceptor to the
sewer, shall at all times be equipped with a water seal or vertically downward
turned elbow of ninety degrees (90°) and not less than ten inches (10") in
length below the bottom of the outlet of such interceptor.
   C.   The Waste Water Superintendent shall perform bi-annual inspections or
whenever in the judgment of the Waste Water Superintendent of the City, there
is reason to believe that this section is being violated, the Waste Water
Superintendent or any of the employees of the Waste Water Department on the
orders of the Superintendent, shall have the right and duty at all reasonable
times during daylight hours to enter such place for the purpose of inspecting
the same to determine whether in fact this section is being violated. The
refusal to admit the Waste Water Department employee(s) into any such place for
the purpose above mentioned by any owner, tenant, manager or occupier of any
such place shall be considered a violation of this section. (Ord. 280, 2-14-
2013)
17-414: PENALTY:
   A.   A person who continues prohibited discharges is guilty of a misdemeanor
and, upon conviction, is punishable as provided in section
1-108 of this Code.
   B.   In addition to proceeding under authority of subsection A of this
section, the City is entitled to pursue all other criminal and civil remedies
to which it is entitled under authority of statutes or other ordinances against
a person continuing prohibited discharges.
   C.   The City reserves the right to terminate service to any customer that
fails to pay bills when due or discharges any prohibited wastes into the sewer
system. (Ord. 280, 2-14-2013)
CHAPTER 5
REFUSE, GARBAGE COLLECTION
SECTION:
17-501: Definitions
17-502: System Of Storing Garbage And Trash
17-503: Additional Regulations On Storing And Picking Up Waste
17-504: Containers And Dumpsters
17-505: Collection Schedule; Fees
17-506: Garbage Billings With Electric Bills
17-507: Dumpsters In Volume Commercial Establishments
17-508: Scattering Garbage Or Trash
17-509: Nuisance
17-509-1: City Courtesy Dumpsters
17-510: Penalty
17-501: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
BULKY WASTE: Waste material generated by residences that include large,
cumbersome, or heavy items that are not normally put into bags or boxes for
disposal, including, but not limited to, furniture, appliances, carpet,
mattresses, box springs, bicycles and large quantities of unbundled brush.
COMMERCIAL CONTAINER: A container or dumpster or a size agreed upon between the
business, commercial or industrial customer and the city, such dumpster to be
furnished by the city or its contractor.
COMMERCIAL WASTE: Waste material generated by commercial establishments, but
does not include bulky waste or industrial waste generated by an industry and
hazardous material as is listed or characterized as such by the United States
EPA or the appropriate state authority, including, but not limited to, the
department of environmental quality.
RESIDENTIAL CONTAINER: A ninety five (95) gallon cart to be furnished by the
city or its contractor and, for excess residential waste, plastic garbage bags
and other receptacles which may be approved by the sanitation officer or the
city manager.
RESIDENTIAL WASTE: Waste material that is typically generated by a residence in
normal quantities that is reasonably containerized and shall include garbage,
rubbish, ashes, grass clippings and tree limbs tied and bundled in lengths not
to exceed four feet (4'). (2000 Code §
17-501)
17-502: SYSTEM OF STORING GARBAGE AND TRASH:
It shall be the duty of the occupant of each dwelling where refuse or garbage
is being picked up at the time of the passage of this chapter, or occupant of
each business or industrial establishment, to comply with the provisions of
this chapter pertaining to the storage of refuse and garbage:
   A.   All residential waste from dwellings shall be stored in such container
as hereinabove referred to. Refuse and garbage on the scheduled day of pick up
shall be located at a single place on each premises, which place shall be
easily accessible to the street or alley from which collections are made.
Refuse or garbage in excess of that which will fit into such container may be
placed in plastic garbage bags and placed alongside such cart on the day for
scheduled pick up of garbage at such dwelling. The city or its contractor
reserves the right to refuse to collect garbage and trash in containers which
are not easily accessible;
   B.   "Bulky waste", as defined in section
17-501 of this chapter, shall be brought by occupant to a large dumpster or
dumpsters at city hall or property adjacent thereto, and deposited therein. Any
such person making any deposit in the large dumpster shall pay the sum of three
dollars ($3.00), or as otherwise set by the council by motion or resolution,
for each pickup load, or part thereof, or the equivalent thereof, placed in the
large dumpster. Such sum shall be paid to the city clerk's office during office
hours and to the police dispatcher during hours when the city clerk's office is
closed;
   C.   For business, commercial or industrial establishments, all garbage for
business, commercial or industrial establishments shall be served by a city or
contractor owned ninety five (95) gallon cart or dumpster type receptacle.
Trash dumpsters shall be located outside of the building, shall be ratproof and
shall have waterproof lids. Business, commercial or industrial dumpsters shall
be single or multiple units of sufficient capacity to fully contain all trash
accumulated between collection periods with the lids or covers closed.
Business, commercial and industrial trash containers located outside of
buildings shall not be located directly under downspouts or eaves where they
will be deluged with water during storms. No business, commercial or industrial
trash containers located in any alley shall block traffic in the alley. All
commercial waste shall be stored inside of such container or dumpster.
Commercial waste placed therein shall be baled or placed in baskets, boxes or
hampers which can be dumped without the necessity of collectors gathering up
loose trash or handled in such manner as may be approved by the sanitary
officer, or, if none, appointed by the city manager. Heavy paper or cardboard
boxes may be nested or stacked within a trash container;
   D.   No person shall damage, destroy or remove from the premises of a
dwelling or the premises of a business, commercial or industrial establishment
any city owned or contractor owned garbage container or dumpster. If any such
container (cart) or dumpster is stolen, lost or needs to be replaced for any
reason, other than negligence of the city or its contractor, such shall be done
by the occupant of the residence or the owners or lessees of any such business,
commercial or industrial establishment;
   E.   No person shall deposit any refuse or waste in any container or
dumpster which serves a residence or business owned or occupied by another as a
residence, or into a dumpster that serves a business establishment owned or
leased by another;
   F.   In addition to the regulations set forth above, in order to protect the
public health, storage of garbage shall be in such manner as is approved by the
sanitary officer or if none appointed, the city manager. (2000 Code §
17-502)
17-503: ADDITIONAL REGULATIONS ON STORING AND PICKING UP WASTE:
It shall be the duty of the occupant or occupants of each dwelling, and of the
occupant or occupants of each business, commercial or industrial establishment,
to comply with the provisions of the chapter pertaining to the storage of
garbage or waste:
   A.   The placement or parking of vehicles in alleys where trash containers
are located or in the city right of way so as to deny access to the bin is
expressly prohibited. The city or its contractor reserves the right to refuse
to collect garbage and waste in containers or dumpsters which are not easily
accessible by reason of parked cars or other such obstructions. The placement
of any items on the ground beside the container or dumpster that would normally
be placed in the container thereby causing litter is expressly prohibited,
except on the scheduled day of pick up. Refuse that is in excess of what will
fit in the container may be placed in plastic garbage bags alongside the
container for pick up. The occupant will take any action necessary to see that
such garbage bag is not broken and the garbage scattered;
   B.   For business, commercial or industrial establishments, all garbage and
waste from business, commercial or industrial establishments shall be placed in
the container or dumpsters provided. Cardboard boxes which are placed in the
dumpsters may be nested or broken down. The same restrictions and prohibitions
that apply to dwellings in subsection A of this section shall apply to
business, commercial and industrial establishments covered by this section;
   C.   No person shall damage, destroy or remove from the premises of a
dwelling or the premises of a business, commercial or industrial establishment
any container or dumpster. The placement of any items on or around the
container or dumpster that would thereby cause damage to private property or to
a garbage truck is expressly prohibited. Any malicious mischief, such as moving
or defacing, setting fire to container or dumpster contents, or causing the
contents of the container or dumpster to burn by the placement of hot ashes in
the container or dumpster, is expressly prohibited;
   D.   In addition to the regulations set forth above, in order to protect the
public health, storage of garbage shall be in such manner as is approved by the
sanitary officer, and if none appointed, then the city manager. (2000 Code §
17-503)
17-504: CONTAINERS AND DUMPSTERS:
All containers and dumpsters shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition at
all times and shall be kept free of rodents, pests and stinging insects.
Whenever a container or dumpster has deteriorated or has been damaged and is no
longer sanitary, rodentproof or capable of retaining its load, it shall be
repaired or replaced by the occupant or occupants. When an occupant fails to
repair or replace unsatisfactory containers or dumpsters after notice of this
condition has been given by the city or its contractor, further collections
will be discontinued until proper containers or dumpsters have been provided.
The city or its contractor shall not be responsible for cleaning of containers
and dumpsters where the character of the contents is such that ordinary efforts
of dumping and shaking will not completely free the contents from the container
or dumpster. It shall be the responsibility of the occupant or occupants of the
premises to clean all containers and dumpsters of all residual deposits which
cannot be dislodged by the ordinary effort of dumping and shaking. (2000 Code §
17-504)
17-505: COLLECTION SCHEDULE; FEES:
   A.   It is declared to be the policy of the city to collect garbage and
refuse from each dwelling, business, commercial or industrial establishment,
cafe, eating house, grocery or market in accordance with a schedule adopted by
the city council.
   B.   The occupants of each premises shall pay the fees monthly to the city
for the removal of such refuse. Such fees shall be set by resolution or motion
of the council, so long as it has a lease on the sanitation system, for such
classes of users as the council or the Stroud utilities authority may set.
(2000 Code §
17-505)
17-506: GARBAGE BILLINGS WITH ELECTRIC BILLS:
If electric and water accounts for a premises are billed to separate persons,
the garbage fee will be to the individual maintaining the electric accounts.
(2000 Code §
17-506)
17-507: DUMPSTERS IN VOLUME COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS:
Dumpster containers shall be used for all volume commercial establishments.
(2000 Code §
17-507)
17-508: SCATTERING GARBAGE OR TRASH:
No person shall molest garbage or trash cans or containers and no person, other
than duly authorized employees of the city, shall open such cans or containers
without the express permission of the owner. (2000 Code §
17-508)
17-509: NUISANCE:
The storage of garbage and trash in cans and containers prescribed by this
chapter and the regular collecting thereof by the sanitation department, upon
payment of fees and charges provided in this chapter, is hereby declared to be
essential to the efficient operation of the department and to prevention of
disease and protection of public health. Scattering of garbage and trash,
storage of garbage or trash except in cans and containers prescribed by this
chapter, or the accumulation of garbage or trash by reason of nonpayment of
fees or charges for its removal, is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and
a violation of this chapter. Under no circumstances shall garbage or trash be
dumped or stored on any street or any alley or on any lot, without being placed
in proper cans or containers as prescribed herein. Under no circumstances shall
industrial wastes or manure be dumped or stored on any street or in any alley.
(2000 Code §
17-509)
17-509-1: CITY COURTESY DUMPSTERS:
   A.   The city courtesy dumpsters will not longer be located north of city
hall at 221 West 2nd Street (formerly T.H. Rogers Lumber Company yard). The new
location shall be a fenced area located near the city animal control shelter,
west of the water treatment plant located at 1201 East 7th Street (between
Allied Road and Route 66).
   B.   The courtesy dumpsters will be monitored by an attendant to make sure
only approved items are dumped. The following shall not be allowed in the
dumpsters:
      1.   Tires;
      2.   Batteries;
      3.   Hazardous chemicals;
      4.   Construction materials;
      5.   Brush, branches;
      6.   Paint (unless filled with kitty litter to absorb liquid);
      7.   Metal;
      8.   Furniture;
      9.   White goods (appliances, refrigerators, stoves, water heaters, air
conditioning units and like durable items).
   C.   The courtesy dumpster business hours are:
      1.   Sunday and Monday, closed;
      2.   Tuesday through Friday, eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to twelve o'clock
(12:00) noon, and one o'clock (1:00) P.M. to four o'clock (4:00) P.M.;
      3.   Saturday, eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to twelve o'clock (12:00) noon.
   D.   The police department will no longer provide a key for accessing the
dumpster after business hours. Persons dumping after hours are subject to a
fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for illegal dumping.
   E.   The courtesy dumping fees shall be as follows: (Ord. 243, 8-13-2009,
eff. retroactive to 7-1-2009)
      1.   Current City Utility Customers: A current utility bill from the city
of Stroud and a photo ID must be presented to the attendant prior to dumping.
Stroud utility customers may dump one pickup load per month for no charge and
an additional charge as set by resolution of the city council for each
additional pickup load. The fee must be paid at city hall prior to dumping and
a receipt must be shown.
      2.   Nonutility Customers: Customers who do not have a utility account
with the city shall be required to pay and present a receipt from city hall
prior to dumping. A charge as set by resolution of the city council per pickup
load will apply. (Ord. 243, 8-13-2009, eff. retroactive to 7-1-2009; amd. 2011
Code)
      3.   Other: Current city utility customers who present a utility bill
with a photo ID may dump one pickup load per month of household trash or debris
at the city of Prague landfill at no cost. Refuse which may be dumped at the
city of Prague landfill may not contain commercial or construction debris.
(Ord. 243, 8-13-2009, eff. retroactive to 7-1-2009)
17-510: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of any
section or part of a section of this chapter shall be guilty of an offense
against the city and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined as provided in
section
1-108 of this code. (2000 Code §
17-510)
CHAPTER 6
UTILITY USE PERMITS
SECTION:
17-601: Title
17-602: Definitions
17-603: Utility Use Permit Required
17-604: Application For Permit
17-605: Issuance Of Permit
17-606: Liability And Indemnification
17-607: Liability Insurance And Bonds
17-608: Obligations Of Permittee
17-609: Grant Of Authority
17-610: Conditions For Use Of Streets And Alleys
17-611: Erection, Removal And Joint Use Of Poles
17-612: Safety Requirements
17-613: Complaints
17-614: Preferential Or Discriminatory Practices Prohibited
17-615: System Construction And Extension
17-616: Maps, Plats And Reports
17-617: Term Of Permit; Renewals
17-618: Rates
17-619: Permit Fees
17-620: Transfers
17-621: Procedure; Public Hearing
17-622: Procedure On Termination Of Permit
17-623: Revocation Of Permit
17-624: Amendments
17-625: Acceptance
17-626: Interpretation
17-601: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the UTILITY PERMIT CHAPTER. (2000 Code §
17-601)
17-602: DEFINITIONS:
In the construction of this chapter, the definitions of capitalized terms and
the construction of words and phrases shall be in conformity with the code and
ordinances of the city and with the constitution, statutes and laws of the
state. In addition, the following definitions and rules of construction shall
be observed, unless inconsistent with the manifest intent of the legislative
body or the context clearly requires otherwise:
CUSTOMER OR CUSTOMERS: Any person or entity receiving utility service from and
as a customer of the permittee.
GROSS REVENUES: Any and all compensation and other considerations received
directly by a permittee from customers in payment for regularly furnished
utility service, including initial lump sum payments, if any, and connection
charges, exclusive of any taxes on services furnished by the permittee imposed
directly on the customer by the city or by the state, or any other governmental
unit, and collected by the permittee for such governmental unit.
PERMIT: A utility use permit issued by the city pursuant to this chapter.
PERMITTEE: Any person, firm, association or corporation to whom a permit has
been issued by the city.
UTILITY SERVICE: The providing or furnishing of power, light, heat, gas,
electricity, water, sanitary sewer, telephone or cable television service by
the permittee to a customer.
UTILITY SYSTEM: The equipment, fixtures and facilities of the permittee
utilized to provide utility service to customers. (2000 Code §
17-602)
17-603: UTILITY USE PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   No person, firm, association or corporation shall construct, operate or
maintain a utility system within the city involving the use of any streets,
alleys, easements or ways of the city without having first procured a utility
use permit from the city.
   B.   Permittees holding a valid permit and who propose to extend, revise,
improve or conduct maintenance or repair operations with respect to permittee's
utility system within the city shall not be required to obtain any additional
permit under this chapter, provided notice is duly given to the city of such
proposed operations or improvements in the manner hereinafter set forth in this
chapter. (2000 Code §
17-603)
17-604: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
The application for a permit shall be made in writing to the city clerk, and
shall contain the following information:
   A.   Applicant's name, mailing address, street address (if different from
mailing address), telephone number, and names of persons authorized to act on
behalf of applicant with respect to the permit;
   B.   A statement showing whether applicant is an individual, corporation,
association or partnership, and the names and addresses of partners or
principal officers, as the case may be;
   C.   A statement that the applicant, by acceptance of the permit, will
comply with all ordinances of the city and accepts all the terms of the permit
and regulations imposed by the ordinances and code of the city;
   D.   A plat in accordance with section
