17-616 of this chapter, showing the general location of all pipelines, buried
lines, poles, wires, lines, installations and facilities used or to be used
within the municipal limits of the city, particularly those located or to be
located in, on, under or over streets, alleys, easements and ways of the city;
   E.   The date on which the utility system was placed in operation or is
proposed to be placed in operation;
   F.   In the instance of proposed construction or expansion of a utility
system, a general description of the project, including the location of such
installations or improvements, and the estimated time of commencement and of
completion of such work;
   G.   Evidence that applicant has duly received from state and federal
regulatory agencies any licenses, consents or other authorizations necessary
under applicable law for the applicant to construct, maintain and operate the
utility system, if applicable;
   H.   Evidence that applicant currently has in force the liability insurance
and bonds required pursuant to section
17-607 of this chapter; and
   I.   A copy of applicant's current schedule of rates or rate tariff,
applicable or to be applicable to customers within the city. (2000 Code §
17-604)
17-605: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT:
The city clerk, acting on behalf of the city, shall issue a permit upon
completion of the following:
   A.   Satisfactory showing by the applicant that it has complied with all the
provisions of this chapter which are applicable at the time of issuance of the
permit; and
   B.   A public hearing has been held as herein required and the city has
determined that the applicant's legal, character, financial, technical and
other qualifications are satisfactory, and in the instance of proposed
construction, that applicant's construction arrangements are feasible, adequate
and in the best interests of the city and its inhabitants; provided, that
subject to subsection A of this section and the submittal of a properly
completed application pursuant to section
17-604 of this chapter, with respect to utilities already doing business within
the city under existing franchises or gross receipts tax ordinances on the
effective date hereof, such public hearing shall not be required. (2000 Code §
17-605)
17-606: LIABILITY AND INDEMNIFICATION:
The permittee shall indemnify and hold harmless the city at all times during
the term of the permit against all damages, including, but not limited to,
damages arising out of the installation, maintenance and operation of the
permittee's utility system, whether or not any act or omission complained of is
authorized, allowed or prohibited by the permit and this chapter, and all
reasonable expenses of the city incurred in defending itself; provided,
however, that in the event of any claim or claims being prosecuted against the
city, the permittee shall have the right to defend against the same, and to
settle or discharge same in such manner as it may see fit, and the city shall
give prompt written notice to the permittee of the presentation or prosecution
of such claims. (2000 Code §
17-606)
17-607: LIABILITY INSURANCE AND BONDS:
The permittee, during the term of the permit, shall have and maintain a general
public liability insurance policy, under the terms of which the permittee shall
be insured to the extent of not less than five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00) for any injury to any one person, one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) for injuries per occurrence, and five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00) for damage or injury to any property, in connection with the
construction, operation and maintenance of permittee's utility system. In lieu
of insurance, the permittee shall be allowed to provide evidence satisfactory
to the city council of self-insurance by demonstrating financial capabilities
adequate to cover such losses. Any such insurance policies, and any such plan
of self-insurance shall make the city an additional insured, and shall cover
the permittee and the city for any injury or damage sustained by any persons
from any negligent act committed by the permittee, or any of its agents or
employees, during the course of installation, maintenance or operation of its
utility system within the city. The permittee shall also have and maintain any
bonds required by the state or any state or federal regulatory agency for the
operation of its utility system, and shall provide evidence thereof to the city
upon reasonable request. Any insurance or bonds required hereunder shall be
executed by companies authorized to do business in the state, and current
certificates of insurance shall be furnished to the city. (2000 Code §
17-607)
17-608: OBLIGATIONS OF PERMITTEE:
The permittee shall in full compliance with the standards and regulations
applicable to such permittee by the state and federal regulatory agencies
having jurisdiction:
   A.   Maintain its utility system in a good and safe condition;
   B.   Render efficient service to customers, including, but not limited to,
promptly making repairs to minimize service interruptions, insofar as
reasonably possible, and by maintaining either an office, or a local or toll
free telephone number whereby customers may contact permittee to register
complaints, advise of service interruptions or mechanical malfunctions and
otherwise avail themselves of permittee's services; and
   C.   Cooperate with the city in case of emergency or disaster to help assure
the shutoff of malfunctioning utility lines or facilities and the prompt repair
or restoration of service, in coordination with the city's efforts to maintain,
repair or restore the use of streets, alleys and utilities of the city. (2000
Code §
17-608)
17-609: GRANT OF AUTHORITY:
During the term of the permit, the permittee is granted the right and privilege
to use the public ways of the city in order to engage in the business of
operating its utility system in the city, and for that purpose, to erect,
install, construct, repair, replace, reconstruct, maintain, operate and retain
in, over, under, upon, across and along any public street, alley or easement
now laid out or dedicated, or which may be hereinafter dedicated, and which is
described in the application of permittee, within the city, such poles, wires,
cables, conductors, ducts, conduit vaults, manholes, pipelines, pumping
stations, and such other property as may be reasonably necessary and pertinent
to permittee's utility system, and in addition, to use, operate, maintain or
provide similar facilities or properties rendered or leased from other persons,
firms or corporations, including, but not limited to, a public utility or other
grantee franchised or permitted to do business in the city. Provided, this
right shall be nonexclusive, and the city shall have the right to grant a
similar use and permit to others, and the right to grant other uses of streets
and alleys of the city. (2000 Code §
17-609)
17-610: CONDITIONS FOR USE OF STREETS AND ALLEYS:
The permittee shall be subject to the following conditions with respect to the
use of the streets, alleys and ways of the city:
   A.   Use: All transmission and distribution lines, structures and equipment
erected or maintained by the permittee within the city shall be located at the
places authorized by the city, and so located as to cause minimum interference
with the proper use of streets, alleys and easements, and to cause minimum
interference with the rights or reasonable convenience of adjoining property
owners. The permittee shall give the city notice of any proposed change or
construction of equipment prior to making such changes, and shall furnish
construction plans to the city regarding the type of facilities intended to be
constructed, and the particular location thereof;
   B.   Restoration: In the case of any disturbance of pavement, sidewalk,
driveway or other surface, the permittee shall, at its own cost and expense and
in a manner approved by the city, promptly replace and restore any public
paving, sidewalk, driveway or surface of any street, alley or easement
disturbed so as to leave it in as good a condition as before the work was
commenced, failing which the city shall, after providing reasonable notice to
permittee, be entitled to make such restoration and the permittee shall be
liable for the reasonable cost thereof;
   C.   Relocation: In the event that at any time during the period of the
permit the city shall elect to change the grade of or alter any street, alley
or easement, upon reasonable notice by the city, the permittee shall move, re-
lay and relocate its poles, wires, cables, lines and other fixtures at its own
expense;
   D.   Temporary Removal Of Wire For Building Moving: The permittee shall,
upon the request of any person holding a building removal permit issued by the
city, temporarily raise or lower its wires to permit moving of buildings, the
expense of which shall be paid by the person requesting the same. The permittee
shall be authorized to require such payment in advance. The permittee shall be
entitled to be given at least forty eight (48) hours notice to arrange for
temporary wire changes;
   E.   Tree Trimming: The permittee shall be authorized to trim trees upon and
overhanging streets, alleys, sidewalks and public easements so as to prevent
the branches of such trees from coming in contact with the wires, cables and
other equipment of the permittee. All trimming shall be subject to the
supervision and direction of the city and at the expense of the permittee; and
   F.   Placement Of Fixtures And Equipment: The permittee shall not place
poles, cable, pipelines or other fixtures where such equipment will interfere
with telephone wire or conduit, water hydrants, water or sewer mains, gas lines
or other public utilities existing at the time of placement. The city shall
have and retain the right to reasonably regulate the erection or construction
of any transmission line or pipeline structure or equipment and to designate
where such lines shall be placed. Permittee shall file with the city clerk
construction plans at least fourteen (14) days prior to installation, except in
case of emergency or of repairs to existing equipment, when notice reasonable
under the circumstances shall be given. (2000 Code §
17-610)
17-611: ERECTION, REMOVAL AND JOINT USE OF POLES:
   A.   No poles, conduits, or other wire holding structures shall be erected
or installed by the permittee after the effective date hereof without prior
approval of the city, acting through its engineer or utilities manager, as to
location, height, type of structure and other pertinent aspects. The location
of any poles, conduit or wire holding structure of the permittee shall not be a
vested right and such structures, conduit or poles shall be moved or modified
by the permittee at its own expense upon order and upon reasonable notice by
the city.
   B.   Where poles, conduits or other wire holding structures of any public
utility or of the city are available for use by the permittee, the city may
require the permittee to use such poles, conduits and structures if the
permission and consent of such public utility or the city can be obtained by
the permittee, the structure is adequate for such use, and if the terms of the
use available to the permittee are reasonable under the circumstances.
   C.   Where a public utility serving the city desires to make use of the
poles, conduits or other wire holding structures of the permittee, but
agreement therefor with the permittee cannot be reached, the city, by action of
the city council, may require the permittee to permit such use for such
consideration and upon such terms as the council shall determine to be just and
reasonable, if such use is found not to unreasonably interfere with the
permittee's operation; and provided further, that such use shall meet the
minimum safety standards of the applicable provisions of the national
electrical safety code.
   D.   Where city owned utility poles are available for use by the permittee,
the permittee shall pay the city the same pole rental per annum as paid by the
permittee for the use of poles owned by other public utilities. (2000 Code §
17-611)
17-612: SAFETY REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   The permittee shall at all times employ ordinary care and shall install
and maintain is equipment and installations as required by the Oklahoma
corporation commission or other state or federal regulatory body having
jurisdiction over permittee, so as to impose no unreasonable risk of harm to
the public, and shall employ and have available methods and devices commonly
used in permittee's industry to adequately respond to failures and accidents
which are likely to cause damage, injuries or nuisance to the public. Provided,
in the event permittee is not subject to the jurisdiction of a state or federal
regulatory agency with respect to its operations and the safety thereof, then
permittee shall cause all of its installations to be made and operated in
accordance with the building, electrical and other safety codes of the city and
of the national electrical safety code, as adopted by the corporation
commission of Oklahoma (NESC). Provided further, in the event there is a
conflict between the applicable provisions of the safety codes of the city and
of the NESC, the provisions of the NESC shall prevail.
   B.   All structures and all lines, equipment and connections in, over, under
and upon the streets and alleys, wherever situated or located, shall be at all
times kept and maintained in a safe, suitable, substantial condition and in
good repair and order.
   C.   The permittee shall have and maintain either a local telephone number
or a toll free telephone number where members of the public can call permittee
to report failures or dangerous situations with respect to permittee's
operations and facilities, and shall have a sufficient number of employees
within a reasonable distance of the city so as to be able to provide safe,
adequate and prompt service to customers and respond to emergencies or outages
in a reasonable time. (2000 Code §
17-612)
17-613: COMPLAINTS:
Permittee shall use its reasonable efforts to respond to and resolve complaints
of customers and of residents of the city regarding permittee's service,
operations or facilities. Should a complaint be unresolved, the city shall have
the right to meet jointly with the permittee and the person registering the
complaint, in an effort to fully discuss and resolve such matters. Nothing
herein shall be construed as creating an obligation on the part of the city to
arbitrate or settle any dispute or complaint. (2000 Code §
17-613)
17-614: PREFERENTIAL OR DISCRIMINATORY PRACTICES PROHIBITED:
The permittee shall not, with respect to rates, charges, service facilities,
rules, regulations or other aspects of its service, make or grant any
preference or advantage to any person or subject any person to any prejudice or
disadvantage, or unreasonably discriminate against any person. Nothing herein
shall be deemed to prohibit the establishment of a graduated scale of charges
and classified rates, based on a rational basis or scheme of classification, to
which any customer coming within such classification would be entitled. (2000
Code §
17-614)
17-615: SYSTEM CONSTRUCTION AND EXTENSION:
   A.   Where permittee is the only provider of its particular service or type
of service within the city, permittee shall use its best efforts to extend its
facilities so as to provide service to all persons in the city requesting such
service, provided such extension is technically, physically and economically
feasible, as reasonably determined by the permittee.
   B.   Each permittee under this chapter, whether or not permittee is a sole
provider of service, shall, as a condition of retaining its permit, promptly
advise the city in writing of any and all extensions to its system within the
city, and shall provide the city clerk with drawings or plats showing the
general location of such extensions, so as to allow the city to have and
maintain an up to date plat of the generalized location of all of permittee's
facilities within the city. (2000 Code §
17-615)
17-616: MAPS, PLATS AND REPORTS:
   A.   Each permittee shall file annually with the city clerk, not later than
ninety (90) days after the end of the permittee's fiscal year, a report
summarizing:
      1.   In the case of permittees not subject to a gross receipts tax or
franchise tax as provided in subsection 17-619B of this chapter, the gross
revenues received by permittee for its operations within the city for such
fiscal year; or
      2.   In the case of permittees subject to the provisions of subsection
17-619B of this chapter, the gross revenues required to be reported under such
franchise or gross receipts tax ordinance. Further, such report shall indicate
any changes in the officers, partners or management personnel occurring since
the permittee's last report.
   B.   Each permittee shall provide to the city clerk a current plat or map
showing the general location of its utility system within the city, on a yearly
basis. In addition, permittee shall provide the city clerk with maps or plats
regarding system extensions as required in subsection 17-615B of this chapter.
The maps or plats shall be and remain the personal property of the permittee,
shall be used only to provide general information as to the location of the
utility system and shall be used by the city only to perform generalized
planning for the maintenance and growth of its infrastructure. It is hereby
declared in the interests of protecting the health, welfare and safety of the
general public that the aforementioned maps shall not be construed to be public
records, and therefore shall not be available to the public, except as required
under the Oklahoma open records act. The city or its employees shall not
knowingly allow the maps or plats to be used in any way that may cause any harm
to the permittee through damages to the permittee's facilities or through
allowing any unfair competitive advantage to any utility.
   C.   Nothing herein shall serve to relieve or be construed to relieve the
city or any member of the public from obligations imposed under 63 Oklahoma
Statutes sections 142.1 through 142.11, the underground facilities damage
prevention act, or similar applicable laws regarding use of the Oklahoma "one
call" system. (2000 Code §
17-616)
17-617: TERM OF PERMIT; RENEWALS:
   A.   Each permit issued hereunder shall be issued for an initial term of one
year from its date.
   B.   Permits shall be renewable for an additional term of one year, and may
continue to be renewed from year to year, so long as permittee remains in
compliance with this chapter.
   C.   Permits shall be deemed to be automatically renewed from year to year
without any further action on the part of the permittee, so long as permittee
continues to pay the fees provided for herein, and otherwise continues to
perform in accordance with this chapter. (2000 Code §
17-617)
17-618: RATES:
Rates charged for the public services provided by permittee shall be subject to
review and regulation by the city (unless exclusive jurisdiction thereof is
vested in an agency of the state or federal government), in accordance with
Oklahoma constitution article 18, section 7, and with this code and ordinances
of the city, and other applicable provisions of the constitution and laws of
the state. With respect to rates over which the city has power to regulate, no
rate changes shall become effective until approved by the city council after
public hearing. (2000 Code §
17-618)
17-619: PERMIT FEES:
   A.   Subject to the provisions of subsection B of this section, in
consideration of the issuance of the permit and the granting of the privileges
thereunder, the permittee shall pay to the city the sum of not to exceed three
percent (3%) of the gross revenues derived by the permittee from operation of
its utility system within the city for the year in which the permit is in
effect. The fee shall be payable in arrears, in quarterly installments, on or
prior to the tenth of the months of January, April, July and October, as
applicable, commencing on the first day of the calendar quarter next following
the issuance of the permit, and quarterly thereafter so long as the permit is
in effect, and the proceeds thereof shall be placed in the general revenue fund
of the city.
   B.   In lieu of the fee imposed by subsection A of this section, any
permittee:
      1.   Subject to payment of the city gross receipts tax pursuant to
ordinance 143, or other ordinance of the city imposing a tax on the gross
receipts from residential and commercial sales of gas, electricity or water
within the city; or
      2.   Subject to a franchise tax pursuant to a franchise from the city
duly granted in accordance with article 18, section 5(a) of the Oklahoma
constitution, and approved by city voters at an election held for that purpose,
shall be permitted to pay such tax, and the payment of such tax shall be deemed
to be in lieu of payment of the fee imposed by this chapter, and in full
satisfaction thereof.
   C.   The city shall have the right to have access to, and to audit the books
and records of any permittee, with respect to determining the fees payable
pursuant to this chapter. The exercise of audit rights by the city shall not
unreasonably interfere with permittee's ordinary business operations. (2000
Code §
17-619)
17-620: TRANSFERS:
The permit shall not be transferable, except with the express consent of the
city council after public hearing. Nothing herein shall prevent the permittee
from pledging its assets as security for the purpose of obtaining financing.
(2000 Code §
17-620)
17-621: PROCEDURE; PUBLIC HEARING:
Any public hearing required herein shall be held only after notice thereof is
authorized by the city council, and notice is published at least twice on two
(2) consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, with
the first publication thereof being at least ten (10) days prior to the
hearing, and with a copy of the notice being mailed to the permittee at least
ten (10) days prior to the hearing. The notice shall state the matter to be
heard, the time and place of the hearing, and that at the hearing any
interested person may appear and be heard. The cost of publication of such
notice shall be borne by the person requesting the hearing, if other than the
city. The city council shall review the results of the public hearing and shall
approve the issuance of the permit by the city clerk upon a showing that the
requirements of this chapter have been satisfied by the applicant. (2000 Code §
17-621)
17-622: PROCEDURE ON TERMINATION OF PERMIT:
Upon the termination of the permit, whether by revocation, expiration by virtue
of nonpayment of fees, or other causes, the right of the permittee shall cease,
and it shall, subject to the provisions of section
17-626 of this chapter, and unless constrained by obligations under the rules
and regulations of a state or federal regulatory agency having jurisdiction
thereof, within the earliest reasonable time, remove its property and
facilities from the streets, alleys and easements of the city, and shall
restore the surface of such ways to their previous condition. (2000 Code §
17-622)
17-623: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
   A.   In addition to all other rights and powers of the city arising by
virtue of the permit issued by virtue of this chapter, which permit is deemed
to be revocable and nonexclusive, or under other applicable laws, the city
shall have the right to revoke any permit and all rights and privileges
thereunder in the event that the permittee:
      1.   Wilfully violates any provision of this chapter or this code,
including, but not limited to, failure to pay the permit fee within thirty (30)
days after the date the fee is due to the city;
      2.   Becomes insolvent, unable or unwilling to pay its just and owing
debts, or is adjudged bankrupt; or
      3.   Attempts to evade any of the provisions of this chapter or of the
permit by any fraud, deceit or misrepresentation upon the city.
   B.   The city shall not exercise its right of revocation until after the
conduct of a public hearing, affording the permittee an opportunity to appear
and be heard. (2000 Code §
17-623)
17-624: AMENDMENTS:
This chapter, including the fees imposed hereunder, shall be subject to
amendment by action of the city council from time to time as such council shall
deem appropriate. (2000 Code §
17-624)
17-625: ACCEPTANCE:
By acceptance of a permit, the permittee shall be deemed to have agreed to, and
accepted in full, the provisions of this chapter, and the obligations imposed
on the permittee herein. (2000 Code §
17-625)
17-626: INTERPRETATION:
The provisions of this chapter shall not impair the rights of permittees under
existing contracts with the city. If any section, sentence, clause, paragraph
or other portion of this chapter shall conflict or be inconsistent with the
provisions of a written franchise, utility use permit or other contract between
the city and a permittee in effect as of the effective date hereof, then the
provisions of the earlier agreement shall control. Further, if or to the extent
any section, sentence, clause, paragraph or other portion of this chapter shall
conflict or be inconsistent with the applicable rules and regulations of a
state or federal regulatory agency having general jurisdiction over permittee
and its operations, then the applicable rules and regulations of such
regulatory agency shall control. (2000 Code §
17-626)
CHAPTER 7
POWER LINE SITING AND DESIGN BOARD
SECTION:
17-701: Created
17-702: Membership
17-703: Plans, Application
17-704: Underground Lines
17-705: Nonapplicable To Existing Franchisees
17-701: CREATED:
   A.   There is hereby created the city power line siting and design board.
Such board is established pursuant to the directives of house bill 1739 passed
by the Oklahoma state legislature in 2008. Said HB 1739 provides for a right
for electric utilities to use the street and alleyways of the city subject to
and in compliance with the lawful safety requirements of the municipality as to
the matter of constructing and maintaining facilities along, upon, under, and
across thoroughfares.
   B.   The city power line siting and design board is hereby established by
the city to develop valid construction standards and safety rules for the use
of public ways in the city by all utilities, including the city electric
department.
   C.   According to the provisions of HB 1739, cities are directed to
establish methods to encourage the orderly development of electric services,
conserve natural resources, minimize unnecessary use of the public rights of
way, avoid needless and wasteful duplication of electric facilities within the
state and provide safe, economical and cost effective electric service to
retail consumers.
   D.   It shall be the duty of the city power line siting and design board to
ensure that the purposes of HB 1739 are achieved by reviewing all applications
for power line distribution construction in the city. The board shall review
all applications and will approve the application or amend the application by
providing the methods that shall be used to accomplish the construction so that
the construction meets the goals of the retail electric consumer cost
reduction, safety and service efficiency act of 2008. (Ord. 236, 11-16-2010)
17-702: MEMBERSHIP:
The members of the power line siting and design board shall include the city
manager, the public works director, and four (4) members of the community
appointed by the mayor, with confirmation by the city council. The initial
terms for appointed positions one through four (4) will be for one, two (2),
three (3) and four (4) years respectively, with appointments thereafter being
for four (4) year periods of time. The members will appoint a chairperson from
among the members appointed by the mayor and city council. The board will meet
from time to time at the call of the chairperson and on the last Tuesday of
each month. (Ord. 236, 11-16-2010)
17-703: PLANS, APPLICATION:
All construction of all power lines within the city shall be constructed only
after submission of plans for such construction to the city power line siting
and design board. Such plans may be carried out by a utility only after
approval of the construction by the board, with final approval provided by the
city council or the Stroud utilities authority. The city council may approve or
disapprove a recommendation of the board, but it may not amend any
recommendation. It may send an application back to the board for further
review. (Ord. 236, 11-16-2010)
17-704: UNDERGROUND LINES:
HB 1739 found that duplicate overhead power lines are a safety hazard and
should not be permitted. It is therefore the goal of the governing body of the
city that power lines constructed in the future should be underground wherever
possible, and the city power line siting and design board should take all
measures needed to ensure the use of underground facilities by utilities. The
board shall ensure that use of the rights of way are done in such a manner as
to ensure the public safety and the best use of limited rights of way area as
mandated by HB 1739. (Ord. 236, 11-16-2010)
17-705: NONAPPLICABLE TO EXISTING FRANCHISEES:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to electric utilities that hold
a valid franchise for operations in the city. (Ord. 236, 11-16-2010)
